awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Hominin diversity, paleobiology, and behavior at the terminal Pliocene
awd_abstract_narration:
The period of time between 2.5 to 3.0 million years ago (Ma) has long been considered one of the most critical in hominin evolution. At 3.0 Ma, multiple species of Australopithecus are represented in the fossil record across eastern and southern Africa. By 2.5 Ma, Australopithecus mostly died out, and in its place evolved two separate lineages with very different adaptations to the environment. One lineage is our own, Homo, characterized by a pattern of increased brain size and dependence on material culture that has persisted over the last several million years. The other lineage, Paranthropus, lasted over 1 million years, and was represented by three species with unique dental and facial adaptations for potentially eating tough or hard foods. Despite the obvious importance of this interval, it is poorly represented in the fossil record and few fossil specimens have been found that can shed light on the causes and patterns of the origins of these lineages. The Ledi-Geraru Research Project works in a fossiliferous region that includes this important time interval and aims to illuminate the issues relevant to the extinction of Australopithecus and the emergence of Homo and Paranthropus. The investigators will use the results of this work in public science outreach about the hominin lineage, including the critical relationship between environmental variance and hominin adaptations. The project also will foster international collaborations and student training. 
 
In the last decade, the investigators have identified fossiliferous sediments in the Afar region of Ethiopia that range from 2.9 to 2.4 Ma before present. Finds from these sediments include a 2.8 million year old mandible that is the earliest known representative of the genus Homo, and additional fossils suggesting that there were multiple hominin species existing at roughly the same time in the region. In addition, several localities in the Ledi-Geraru Research Project area show evidence that hominins were using stone tools to gain access to animal tissues and resources. Continued paleoanthropological research will be conducted at Ledi-Geraru Project sites to recover additional fossil and archaeological materials and better understand relationships between hominin behaviors and environmental contexts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The major goals of this project were to 1) extend paleontological and geological surveys to focus on, and identify more of, the critical interval after the last known appearance of A. afarensis (2.95 Ma) but prior to the appearance of Homo (2.8 Ma). 2) Increase the sampling of the hominin (early Homo) and non-hominin paleontological record at the 2.8 Ma horizon in the study area to address hypotheses of climate change and hominin evolution. 3) Determine the temporal and spatial distribution of an as yet unknown hominin species recovered in the study area to elucidate the comparative paleoenvironmental contexts of hominin diversity. 4) Reconstruct past habitats and depositional environments at varying spatial and temporal scales, and create and link “paleoscapes” using faunal and geological indicators. 5) Expand and refine the mapping, stratigraphy, and tephra characterization in the study area. 6) Generate 3D structure from motion geological models of important hominin and archaeological localities that can be shared on open databases.

Paleontologically, the team concentrated on refining the context of the several hominin specimens previously recovered in the Gurumaha and Lee Adoyta Fault Blocks, as well as adding to fauna information of the two Golden Sands regions (Lee Adoyta and Asboli). This was done in conjunction with higher resolution stratigraphy and 3D imaging by the geology team. We have determined that there are at least two hominin species deposited within a kilometer of one another, which implies major paleoenvironmental change from Australoptihecus afarensis times (ending at 2.95 Ma in the region) to 2.8 Ma. We also recovered some hominin teeth from slightly younger deposits (2.67Ma) in the Lee Adoyta Basin, which do not belong to the genus Homo. We were finally able to return to the NationalMuseum of Ethiopia in2022 and began working on preparing and analyzing the new faunal specimens collected in 2018 and 2020. This new collection contains some species previously unknown from this area, and indicates patches of more wooded and wetland environments. We are now focusing on whether or not the different hominin species are associated with different mammalian communities using various analytical techniques. 

The geology team of the Ledi-Geraru Research Project refined the geologic framework for our paleontological, paleoanthropological, and archeological research. Our main efforts included a sharpened focus on higher resolution 3D characterization of sedimentary and tectonic architecture of the interiors of the main fault blocks, primarily derived from extensive aerial photogrammetry combined with detailed stratigraphic analyses. This brings the scale of the study closer to that of the paleontological, paleoanthropological, and archeological investigations. We emphasized sandstone sedimentary structures at multiple scales and sampling for petrography and detrital zircon (DZ) studies. U/Pb laser ablation inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry analysis of DZ samples show sediment flux to the basin that is predominantly derived from Oligocene rhyolitic ignimbrites on the western Ethiopian plateau and volcanic rocks of the Chifra Formation along the western Afar margin. Our results are consistent with detrital zircon data from Northern Awash drill cores showing an evolution of sources from largely the western Afar margin ( 2.95 – 2.63 Ma) to roughly equal inputs including the more distal western Ethiopian plateau (~2.63 Ma). An abrupt change in sediment flux between ~2.63 - 2.37 Ma (dominantly western Ethiopian plateau) is likely the result of local tectonic, and therefore hydrologic, reorganization that increased basin compartmentalization in the Afar Depression.

The Tendaho reservoir, developed over the last decade from damming of the Awash River, serves as a potential modern analogue for the paleoenvironmental terrestrial, fluvial, deltaic, and lacustrine facies observed in the sedimentary packages in eastern Ledi-Geraru. Detailed mapping from satellite imagery through time provides insights to the modern autogenic and allogenic processes that are active within the Lower Awash Valley today. Although the geomorphology seen in the Tendaho reservoir is a product of anthropogenic modification, the process of damming and forming a lake via tectonic or volcanogenic processes would yield similar depositional environments. 

Intellectual Merit

Our work has uncovered different hominin species existing together during a critical time period in human evolution. We have also provided important data on the environments and the mammalian communities in which these hominins existed. Further refinement and characterization of sedimentary facies and architecture will provide clearer interpretations of the past environments of these early human ancestors.

Broader Impacts

We have trained six graduate students,  3 females, 4 males, including one Ethiopian scholar in paleontology in both field and lab techniques, as well as geology during the duration of this grant. The work has contributed substantially to their dissertations. In addition, the digital field geology approaches have been adapted to teaching curricula at Arizona State University. Our field operations provided meaningful economic support and respect to the rural communities near the study area.
